description:
Neurospora crassa OR74A is a filamentous fungus that belongs to the phylum Ascomycota. It is a model organism widely used in scientific research, particularly in the fields of genetics, molecular biology, and circadian biology.

N. crassa OR74A is a haploid, self-fertile strain that has been extensively studied and its genome has been fully sequenced. It is known for its rapid growth, easily observable life cycle, and the ability to undergo both asexual and sexual reproduction.

The fungus can be readily cultured in the laboratory, and its cells exhibit a variety of easily observable morphological changes during different stages of development, including the formation of aerial hyphae, conidia (asexual spores), and ascospores (sexual spores).

N. crassa OR74A has been instrumental in the study of numerous biological processes, such as the regulation of gene expression, the mechanisms of circadian rhythms, the control of cellular differentiation, and the molecular basis of fungal pathogenesis. Its versatility and well-characterized genetics have made it a valuable tool for researchers in the field of fungal biology and beyond.
